case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Ahmedabad v. Karamchand Premchand Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 304 of 1958 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 304 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 7, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 19 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 7, 1956, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 19 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellant is the Commissioner of Income-tax, Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the Commissioner of Income-tax, Ahmedabad, and the respondent is a private limited companypany under the name

facts.text: Respondent is Karamchand Premchand Ltd., Ahmedabad, referred to as the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent is a private limited companypany under the name and style of Karamchand Premchand Ltd., Ahmedabad, to be called hereafter as the assesses.

facts.text: Assessee held the managing agency of the Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are these the assessee held the managing agency of the Ahmedabad Manufacturing and Calico Printing Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Assessee had a pharmaceutical business in the Baroda State under the name Sarabhai Chemicals.

anchor.surface_text: It also had a pharmaceutical business in the Baroda State, which was at the relevant time an Indian State run in the name and style of Sarabhai Chemicals.

facts.text: Assessee's business in India showed business profits assessable under the Business Profits Tax Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees business in India  we shall use the expression India in this judgment to mean British India as it was then called in companytra-distinction to an Indian State  showed business profits assessable under the provisions of the Act

facts.text: Baroda business showed a loss in the relevant chargeable accounting periods.

anchor.surface_text: but the business carried on in the name and style of Sarabhai Chemicals in Baroda showed a loss in the relevant chargeable accounting periods which were four in number,

facts.text: Chargeable accounting period 1: April 1, 1946, to December 31, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: namely  1  April 1, 1946, to December 31, 1946  2  January 1, 1947, to December 31, 1947  3  January 1, 1948, to December 31, 1948

facts.text: Chargeable accounting period 2: January 1, 1947, to December 31, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: 2  January 1, 1947, to December 31, 1947  3  January 1, 1948, to December 31, 1948 and  4  January 1, 1949, to March 31, 1949.

facts.text: Chargeable accounting period 3: January 1, 1948, to December 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: 3  January 1, 1948, to December 31, 1948 and  4  January 1, 1949, to March 31, 1949. The assessee claimed that its assessable income in India should be reduced by the loss suffered by it in its business in Baroda.

facts.text: Chargeable accounting period 4: January 1, 1949, to March 31, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: 4  January 1, 1949, to March 31, 1949. The assessee claimed that its assessable income in India should be reduced by the loss suffered by it in its business in Baroda.

facts.text: Assessee claimed that its assessable income in India should be reduced by the loss suffered in Baroda business.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee claimed that its assessable income in India should be reduced by the loss suffered by it in its business in Baroda.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer rejected the assessee's claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer rejected the claim of the assessee and held that the Act did number apply to the business carried on in an Indian State unless profits and gains of that business were received or deemed to have been received in or brought into India.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the contention of the assessee and allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the companytention of the assessee and allowed the appeal. The Department went up in appeal to the Appellate Tribunal,

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal set aside the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and restored that of the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: which held that under the relevant proviso to s. 5 of the Act, profits and losses of a business in an Indian State were number to be taken into companysideration unless they were received or deemed to have been received in or brought into India. In that view of the matter the Tribunal set aside the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and restored that of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Assessee moved four applications to the Tribunal for reference to Bombay High Court in cases numbered 85, 86, 87 and 88 of 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then moved four applications in respect of the four relevant chargeable accounting periods, and by these applications the assessee required the Tribunal to state a case to the High Court of Bombay on the question of law which arose out of its order. These four applications were companysolidated. The Tribunal on being satisfied that a question of law arose out of its order in the four cases numbered as 85, 86, 87 and 88 of 1953-54,

facts.text: Tribunal referred the question to Bombay High Court: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the loss suffered by the assessee in the business of Sarabhai Chemicals should be deducted in computing the business income of the assessee company liable to business profits tax?

anchor.surface_text: referred that question to the Bombay High Court in the following terms Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the loss suffered by the assessee in the business of Sarabhai Chemicals should be deducted in companyputing the business income of the assessee companypany liable to business profits tax ?

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered the question in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the affirmative and came to the companyclusion that the assessee was entitled to deduct the losses incurred by it in its Baroda business and set them off against the profits made in the taxable territories.

facts.text: Appellant obtained a certificate of fitness from High Court and filed present appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the High Court and obtained a certificate of fitness. On that certificate the present appeal has companye to us.

facts.text: Judgment of the Supreme Court delivered by K. DAS, J. on April 28, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: K. Daphtary,Solicitor-General of India,K. N. Rajagopal Sastri and D. Gupta, for the appellant. A. Palkhivala and S. N. Andley, for the respondent. 1960. April 28.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the loss suffered by the assessee in the business of Sarabhai Chemicals should be deducted in computing the business income of the assessee company liable to business profits tax ?

anchor.surface_text: The question then is-does the third proviso to s. 5 exclude that business except in so far as the income, profits or gains of that business are received or deemed to be received in or brought into the taxable territories

holdings.text: The third proviso to s. 5 does not exclude the Baroda business from the purview of the Act but merely exempts income, profits or gains accruing or arising in territories to which the Act does not extend unless received or brought into taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: We have to read and construe the third proviso in the context of the substantive part of s. 5 which takes in the Baroda business and the phraseology of the first and second provisos thereto, which clearly uses the language of excluding the business referred to therein.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantive s.5 includes the business; first and second provisos explicitly exclude business using 'the Act shall not apply to any business'; third proviso uses different language applying only to 'income, profits or gains'; read in context and harmoniously.

holdings.text: The expression 'income, profits or gains' in the third proviso does not include losses, as losses cannot be 'received or brought into' the taxable territories except in accounting sense.

anchor.surface_text: Next, we have to consider what the expression income, profits or gains means. In the context of the third proviso, it cannot include losses because the latter part of the proviso says unless such income, profits or gains are received, etc., into the taxable territories.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of proviso language; consistent meaning throughout proviso; losses not capable of physical receipt or bringing into territory.

holdings.text: The assessee is entitled to deduct losses from Baroda business (Sarabhai Chemicals) against profits in taxable territories (India) in computing taxable profits under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the loss suffered by the assessee in the business of Sarabhai Chemicals should be deducted in computing the business income of the assessee company liable to business profits tax ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Business included under substantive s.5 and treated as one under s.2(3); proviso exempts only profits/gains not losses; unit of tax is business allowing set-off.

holdings.text: The unit of taxation under the Business Profits Tax Act, 1947 is the business to which the Act applies; multiple businesses of same person treated as one.

anchor.surface_text: The word business is defined in s. 2(3) of the Act as including any trade, commerce or manufacture, etc., the profits of which are chargeable according to the provisions of s. 10 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. There are two provisos to this definition clause, and the second proviso states that all businesses to which the Act applies carried on by the same person shall be treated as one business for the purposes of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct from ss.4, 5 and definition in s.2(3) second proviso; consistent scheme of Act.

holdings.text: Substantive part of s.5 applies the Act to the assessee's Baroda business as any part of profits chargeable to income-tax under Indian Income-tax Act s.4 even though in Indian State.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5, in its substantive part, states to which business the Act applies and says that the Act applies to every business of which any part of the profits made during the chargeable accounting period is chargeable to income-tax by virtue of the provisions of sub-cl. (i) or sub-cl.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit terms of s.5 substantive provision; conceded by counsel absent provisos.

holdings.text: The High Court correctly answered the referred question in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the High Court correctly answered the question of law referred to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Correct interpretation of third proviso permits deduction of Baroda losses.

holdings.text: If there is ambiguity in taxing language, benefit given to assessee.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that if there is any ambiguity of language, the benefit of that ambiguity must be given to the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement with High Court; however, proviso language clear without need for ambiguity rule.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Indo-Mercantile Bank Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Losses incurred in business in Indian State can be set off against profits of business in taxable territories under the same head i.e. business income
precedents.cited_holding: the assessee was entitled to such set-off under s. 10(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Murlidhar Mathurawalla Mahajan Association
precedents.cited_proposition: First proviso to s. 24(1) of IT Act bars set-off of Indian State loss only against other heads, not same head (business)
precedents.cited_holding: assessee entitled to set-off loss in Indian State business against profits of same or another business in India under s. 10(1)

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax, Bombay City v. Bhogilal H. Patel, Bombay  3  1952 21 I.T.R. 72

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax, Bombay City v. Bhogilal H. Patel, Bombay  3  . The first two decisions cited above companysidered the effect of s. 24(1), Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, with special reference to the first proviso thereto (as it stood at the time relevant therein) and its impact on s. 10 of the said Act.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax v. Bhogilal H. Patel
precedents.cited_proposition: Third proviso to s.5 of Excess Profits Tax Act excluded the entire business whose profits arose in Indian State, unlike mere profits
precedents.cited_holding: the proviso does not say that the Act shall not apply to the profits of a business... but to any business the whole of the profits of which accrue or arise in an Indian State

It is true that s. 4(3) of the Indian Income-tax Act, as it stood prior to 1939, said that this Act (meaning the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922) shall not apply to certain classes of income

precedents.cited_proposition: "Act shall not apply" to certain income excludes business whose profits are not assessable, no deduction of foreign business losses/expenses

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. The Provident Investment Co. Ltd. 2 . It is true that s. 4(3) of the Indian Income-tax Act, as it stood prior to 1939, said that this Act (meaning the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922) shall not apply to certain classes of income , and in the two decisions cited it was held that the word business meant a business whose profits were being assessed

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. The Provident Investment Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: "Act shall not apply" to certain income excludes business whose profits are not assessable, no deduction of foreign business losses/expenses

Argument's observation of explicit business exclusion language in first/second provisos absent in third provides basis for literal interpretation that third proviso exempts only income/profits/gains, not business or losses.
Argument establishing third proviso targets only income/profits/gains supports holding that losses are not included in that expression.

Argument contrasts explicit business exclusion in first and second provisos with third proviso's language limited to income/profits/gains, directly addressing the issue of whether third proviso excludes the business or only its income/profits/gains.

edges.explanation: The third proviso in c1 grounds the holding h1 on its scope and effect
Literal interpretation excluding losses from plain language of third proviso grounds the holding that losses cannot be 'received or brought into' taxable territories.

Literal interpretation concept that plain language of third proviso exempts only income/profits/gains, not business or losses, directly addresses the interpretive issue on scope of exclusion under third proviso.

Section 4 defines the unit of taxation as the business and levies tax on taxable profits thereof, supporting the holding that losses from the entire business (including Baroda) are deductible against profits in taxable territories.

Section 2(3) second proviso treats all businesses carried on by the same person as one business, grounding the holding that losses from the Baroda business (Sarabhai Chemicals) are deductible against profits in taxable territories.
The proviso treating all businesses of the same person as one addresses the issue of deducting losses from one business (Sarabhai Chemicals) against income from another.

Application of harmonious construction in c9 provides the basis for the holding h2 that 'income, profits or gains' in the third proviso excludes losses, as this interpretation harmonizes the proviso with the main section without rendering parts otiose

Harmonious construction concept c9 directly addresses the interpretive issue i3 by requiring the third proviso to be read in context of the main section and other provisos to determine if it excludes the business or merely exempts profits

anchor.surface_text: We have to read and construe the third proviso in the context of the substantive part of s. 5 which takes in the Baroda business and the phraseology of the first and second provisos thereto, which clearly uses the language of excluding the business referred to therein.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the High Court correctly answered the question of law referred to it.

edges.explanation: By excluding losses from the scope of 'income, profits or gains' receivable/brought into taxable territories under the third proviso, it supports deducting such losses against profits in computing taxable profits under the Act.
Holding h2 interprets the key phrase 'income, profits or gains' in the third proviso, directly addressing whether the proviso excludes the business income beyond remitted profits

anchor.surface_text: Next, we have to consider what the expression income, profits or gains means. In the context of the third proviso, it cannot include losses because the latter part of the proviso says unless such income, profits or gains are received, etc., into the taxable territories.
Accordingly, the High Court correctly answered the question of law referred to it.
